snippet.textDisplay:
Konami should remake this game for 3DS and PSvita, fixing all the flaws it has:

*Play the full game on easy mode instead of just playing a half of it.

*Remove the nitro and mandragora part or making it less frustrating

*More items to use in the inventory

*More comfortable saving points.

*Better camera angles.

*More bosses and levels.

*More comfortable whip controls (maybe locking the enemy by pressing L or R like Legend of Zelda).

*Replace the motorcycles by zombie horses and the chainsaw by an axe (is the mid XIX century).

If that happens, surely this game would end up becoming a masterpiece.

In retrospect the controls were bad (I remember yelling out of pure anger falling off a disappearing platform for the 100th time) but I was a kid, I didn't care about trivial things like that! I loved this game, I loved its music, I loved its locations, I loved its atmosphere, I loved its cosmology, I still love it all! 
One of my favourite N64 titles!

snippet.textDisplay: +ShadowSumac I am partially agree, of course Legends can not be enough in itself to tell the origins of the series. But this is not a sufficient reason to remove it, Igarashi could have very well make his Lament of innocence without removing Legends from the timeline. Besides, Lament of Innocence was a huge disappointment for me. I'm not satisfied with the answers provided to the questions that I asked myself. I prefer the origins told in Lords of Shadow rather than Lament of Innocence.

snippet.textDisplay:
+MauriceTimeofWar It's not as good as Belmont's Revenge, but certainly better than The Adventure (which is not hard, since CVA is a horrible mess). Overall, it's an average game, not exceptionally good, nor exceptionally bad, IMO.


I don't have issues with it being removed from the timeline. It was a mediocre story, which was quite weak for a start of legendary feud between Dracula and Belmont clan. Dracula was never given proper introduction in it, he is just already there and that's it. 


On other hand, story of Lament of Innocence is a full scale dramatic nonsense. It has its good moments and I liked voice acting, but generally it's just typical IGA's run-of-the-mill story (one friend betrays another, an idea, which is present almost in all his games, though arguably the first game, which utilized this plot was KCEK's Legacy of Darkness).


So, both origins are quite bad, for their own reasons. Legends is too low-key and LOI feels boring.
snippet.textOriginal:
+MauriceTimeofWar It's not as good as Belmont's Revenge, but certainly better than The Adventure (which is not hard, since CVA is a horrible mess). Overall, it's an average game, not exceptionally good, nor exceptionally bad, IMO.


I don't have issues with it being removed from the timeline. It was a mediocre story, which was quite weak for a start of legendary feud between Dracula and Belmont clan. Dracula was never given proper introduction in it, he is just already there and that's it. 


On other hand, story of Lament of Innocence is a full scale dramatic nonsense. It has its good moments and I liked voice acting, but generally it's just typical IGA's run-of-the-mill story (one friend betrays another, an idea, which is present almost in all his games, though arguably the first game, which utilized this plot was KCEK's Legacy of Darkness).


So, both origins are quite bad, for their own reasons. Legends is too low-key and LOI feels boring.

snippet.textDisplay:
@SynthWaveFox0
 Just as how Super Mario 64 is more flawed than Super Mario World and Zelda: Ocarina of Time is more flawed than A Link To The Past. The devs had to adapt to making 3D games, its not an easy task. But considering other attempts, Castlevania 64 was fairly successful at entering the third dimension.

I do think SOTN is the weakest of the non-linear Castlevanias. Not a bad game by any means, but compared to the ones that came after(and even Simon's Quest for that matter) it just doesn't compare and is quite tedious(to the point of actually giving Simon's Quest a run for its money).

Personally my personal favorite of the non-linear games would be a tie between Harmony Of Dissonance and Lords Of Shadow 2. But that's just my opinion.

snippet.textDisplay:
Castlevania 64 is by any stretch of the imagination a very fun game. It's got some excellent music and some cool levels, but it is an inherently flawed game. Definitely underrated, and definitely better than what most people say about it, but I still wouldn't say it's anywhere near as good as SotN. And Symphony isn't even in my top five favorite Castlevania games. 

So while yes, I agree that Castlevania 64 is a very fun game, and not enough people give it credit for being a fun game, I simply can't agree that it's as good as SotN. It has too many little problems bogging it down.

But I'm glad you enjoy the game! I actually find it really cool to know I'm not the only one who liked it, and that there are people who hold it in such high regard.


Oh, and this is one of my favorite Castlevania songs, too.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: @killer7sam If you disregard the anime style intros and just look at the gameplay itself, you will see that the game incorporates everything from all the previous Castlevania games in a perfect manner. It has all the monsters, the main musical themes, the special weapons with added powerups plus adds a new one, but most importantly it keeps the feel of a classic Castlevania action game with the whip wielding gameplay. I'd say the only thing it is lacking is a secret option to play as Simon Belmont. ;-)

snippet.textDisplay: As much as the N64 Castlevanias are flawed and hated, I had a LOT of fun with them and I find them to be the most atmospheric 3D entries in the series to date. Lament of Innocence was such a boring, formulaic and joyless game I can barely believe I brought myself to finish it.

snippet.textDisplay: It's a fucking great game, but Legacy of Darkness (basically an updated version) is an absolute masterpiece, one of the best games ever made. I have a theory as to why it has so many haters: It's the same as Nickelback, most people hate on it because everybody else does, when in reality they never even played it. As for the game itself, it may be different from its predecessors, but that does not mean it's bad. The atmosphere is incredible, the gameplay is solid (I never understood why people complain about the controls/camera, I didn't have any trouble with them even when I first played the game) the soundtrack is a masterpiece, the sound design is probably the best on the N64, the scenery/levels are very well designed and feel massive, the graphics are quite good for N64 and the story isn't anything special, but it's there, and has more depth to it and its characters than in most other Castlevania games. That said, there are some flaws. The one that bothers me is that the levels are laid out like an open/semi-open world game (how you can backtrack and all that) but the game is completely linear. If it was at least semi-linear, it probably would've been pretty interesting. Also, I find it a very easy game, even on the Hard difficulty, but that's probably because I beat it about 3 million times.
snippet.textOriginal: It's a fucking great game, but Legacy of Darkness (basically an updated version) is an absolute masterpiece, one of the best games ever made. I have a theory as to why it has so many haters: It's the same as Nickelback, most people hate on it because everybody else does, when in reality they never even played it. As for the game itself, it may be different from its predecessors, but that does not mean it's bad. The atmosphere is incredible, the gameplay is solid (I never understood why people complain about the controls/camera, I didn't have any trouble with them even when I first played the game) the soundtrack is a masterpiece, the sound design is probably the best on the N64, the scenery/levels are very well designed and feel massive, the graphics are quite good for N64 and the story isn't anything special, but it's there, and has more depth to it and its characters than in most other Castlevania games. That said, there are some flaws. The one that bothers me is that the levels are laid out like an open/semi-open world game (how you can backtrack and all that) but the game is completely linear. If it was at least semi-linear, it probably would've been pretty interesting. Also, I find it a very easy game, even on the Hard difficulty, but that's probably because I beat it about 3 million times.

snippet.textDisplay: It's unironically a good game. It still feels like the most natural transition to 3D for Castlevania. All the classic elements are present and built upon.
